list_ex_of_english: There is no licensing of non-inflammable films and anyone can exhibit 16 mm.
My experience is that when one sees on a motorway a truck marked "highly inflammable" one keeps very well away.
The existing controls over vehicles carrying explosives, petrol and certain other inflammable liquids include restrictions on parking.
They are changes, but not basic changes in the safety requirements relating to these inflammable and toxic substances.
One could understand the argument if the fire hazard were coming from the inflammable cargo.
Of about 150 drums washed up none contained toxic chemicals and those which contained inflammable material were blown up.
The airlines warn passengers against carrying inflammable substances in their baggage, by various means including statements in time-tables, pamphlets and tickets, and notices at check-in-points.
If the fire hazard is coming from the engine, how can there be logic in excluding those vehicles carrying a smaller inflammable load?
